title: Which of the following sentences is grammatically correct?
options: I go to school by bus.
I goes to school by bus.
Me take a bus to school.
I am taking a bus to school.
correct_answer: I go to school by bus.
explanation: The subject pronoun 'I' should be used with the base form of the verb 'go'. The other options contain errors in verb usage or word order.

title: Is it correct to use 'whom' in everyday spoken English?
options: True
False
explanation: In modern English, 'whom' is rarely used and is considered formal. Instead, use 'who' for subjects and objects in most cases.

options: I am looking for a job in Spain.
I am looking for a job on Spain.
I am looking for a job at Spain.
I am looking for a job from Spain.
correct_answer: I am looking for a job in Spain.
explanation: The preposition 'in' is used to indicate the country where the job is located.

title: Is it correct to use 'between you and I'?
options: True
False
explanation: The correct usage is 'between you and me'. 'I' is a subject pronoun and should not be used with the preposition 'between'.

title: Choose the correct form of the verb to complete the sentence:
options: I have been studying English for two years.
I has been studying English for two years.
I am studied English for two years.
I study English for two years.
correct_answer: I have been studying English for two years.
explanation: The present perfect continuous tense is formed with 'have/has been + the gerund form of the verb'.

title: Rewrite the following sentence using a more concise expression:
Choose the correct form of the verb to complete the sentence:
options: I will have finished my work by tomorrow.
I will finish my work by tomorrow.
I finish my work by tomorrow.
I am finishing my work by tomorrow.
correct_answer: I will have finished my work by tomorrow.
explanation: The future perfect tense is formed with 'will/shall + have + past participle of the verb'.

title: Is it correct to use 'irregardless' in standard English?
options: True
False
explanation: The word 'irregardless' is not considered standard English. The correct word to use is 'regardless'.
